courses.title: Korean Fundamentals
courses.description: Master the basics of Korean language from greetings to daily conversation

units.title: Greetings & Introductions
units.description: Learn essential Korean greetings and how to introduce yourself

lessons.title: Hello & Goodbye
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Korean greetings change based on formality level. The most common polite greeting is 안녕하세요 (annyeonghaseyo).

Key points:
- 안녕하세요 is used for both 'hello' and 'goodbye' (when leaving someone behind)
- 안녕히 가세요 means 'goodbye' when someone is leaving
- 안녕히 계세요 means 'goodbye' when you are the one leaving
lessons.grammar_tip: When in doubt, use 안녕하세요 - it's polite and works in most situations!

exercises.question: What does 안녕하세요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 안녕하세요 is the standard polite greeting meaning 'hello'

exercises.question: How do you say goodbye when YOU are leaving?
exercises.explanation: 안녕히 계세요 (stay in peace) is said when you are the one leaving

exercises.question: How do you say goodbye when SOMEONE ELSE is leaving?
exercises.explanation: 안녕히 가세요 (go in peace) is said when someone else is leaving

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text

exercises.question: Listen to the full sentence and select what you hear
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Hello. Nice to meet you.'

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a common greeting phrase
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'The weather is nice today.'

exercises.question: You are at a store and the cashier is about to leave for the day. What do you say?
exercises.explanation: Since the cashier is leaving, you say 안녕히 가세요

exercises.question: Nice to meet you.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 안녕하세요 (hello) + 만나서 (meeting) + 반갑습니다 (glad) = Nice to meet you

exercises.question: When did you arrive in Korea?
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the question
exercises.explanation: 언제 (when) + 한국에 (to Korea) + 도착했어요 (did you arrive) = When did you arrive in Korea?

lessons.title: Thank You & Sorry
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Expressing thanks and apologies is essential in Korean culture.

감사합니다 (gamsahamnida) - Thank you (formal)
고마워요 (gomawoyo) - Thank you (informal polite)

죄송합니다 (joesonghamnida) - I'm sorry (formal apology)
미안해요 (mianhaeyo) - I'm sorry (informal polite)
lessons.grammar_tip: Use 감사합니다 with strangers and in formal situations. Use 고마워요 with friends.

exercises.question: What does 감사합니다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 감사합니다 is the formal way to say 'thank you'

exercises.question: What does 죄송합니다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 죄송합니다 is the formal way to apologize

exercises.question: Listen to the sentence and select what you hear
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Thank you very much for your help.'

exercises.question: Listen and identify the apology phrase
exercises.instruction: Listen carefully to the full sentence
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'I'm sorry. I didn't hear well.'

exercises.question: Your boss helped you. How do you thank them?
exercises.explanation: Use 감사합니다 with your boss as it's the most formal

exercises.question: You accidentally bump into a stranger. What do you say?
exercises.explanation: 죄송합니다 is appropriate when apologizing to strangers

exercises.question: How can I help you today?
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the question
exercises.explanation: 오늘 (today) + 어떻게 (how) + 도와 드릴까요 (can I help you) = How can I help you today?

exercises.question: I'm sorry, I don't understand Korean well.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 죄송합니다 (I'm sorry) + 한국어를 (Korean) + 잘 못해요 (can't do well) = I'm sorry, I don't speak Korean well

lessons.title: Self Introduction
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Introducing yourself in Korean follows a pattern:

저는 [name]입니다 - I am [name] (formal)
제 이름은 [name]입니다 - My name is [name] (formal)

Key vocabulary:
저 (jeo) - I (humble/formal)
이름 (ireum) - name
입니다 (imnida) - am/is (formal ending)
lessons.grammar_tip: Always use 저 (not 나) when meeting someone for the first time!

exercises.question: What does 저 mean?
exercises.explanation: 저 is the humble/formal way to say 'I' in Korean

exercises.question: What does 이름 mean?
exercises.explanation: 이름 means 'name' in Korean

exercises.question: Complete the sentence: 저는 민수___
exercises.instruction: Fill in the blank to say 'I am Minsu'
exercises.explanation: 입니다 is the formal copula ('to be') used in introductions

exercises.question: Read the introduction and answer: What is the person's name?
exercises.content_text: 안녕하세요. 저는 김지현입니다. 만나서 반갑습니다.
exercises.explanation: The text says '저는 김지현입니다' (I am Kim Jihyeon)

exercises.question: What does 만나서 반갑습니다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 만나서 반갑습니다 is the formal way to say 'Nice to meet you'

exercises.question: Listen to the introduction and select what you hear
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'I came from America.'

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Pay attention to the verb ending
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'I want to learn Korean.'

exercises.question: Listen to the full introduction
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'My name is Kim Minsu. I'm a university student.'

exercises.question: Where are you from originally?
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the question
exercises.explanation: 원래 (originally) + 어디 (where) + 출신이에요 (are you from) = Where are you from originally?

exercises.question: My name is Jihyun.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 제 (my) + 이름은 (name + topic) + 지현 (name) + 입니다 (is) = My name is Jihyun

exercises.question: I am a university student studying Korean.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 한국어를 공부하는 (studying Korean) + 대학생입니다 (am a university student)

units.title: Numbers & Counting
units.description: Learn Korean number systems and counting

lessons.title: Sino-Korean Numbers 1-10
lessons.description: Numbers used for dates, money, and phone numbers
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Korean has two number systems. Sino-Korean numbers (based on Chinese) are used for:
- Dates and months
- Money
- Phone numbers
- Minutes
- Addresses

1=일, 2=이, 3=삼, 4=사, 5=오
6=육, 7=칠, 8=팔, 9=구, 10=십
lessons.grammar_tip: Think of Sino-Korean numbers as the 'official' numbers for formal things like documents and prices.

exercises.question: What is 'one' in Sino-Korean?
exercises.explanation: 일 (il) is 'one' in Sino-Korean

exercises.question: What number is 삼?
exercises.explanation: 삼 (sam) means 3 in Sino-Korean

exercises.question: What number is 칠?
exercises.explanation: 칠 (chil) means 7 in Sino-Korean

exercises.question: If something costs 오천원, how much is it?
exercises.explanation: 오 (5) + 천 (thousand) + 원 (won) = 5,000 won

exercises.question: What number is 십?
exercises.explanation: 십 (sip) means 10 in Sino-Korean

exercises.question: Listen and identify the price
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'This is 3,000 won.' (삼천 = 3,000)

exercises.question: Listen and select the date phrase
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Today is March 15th.' (삼월 십오일 = 3/15)

exercises.question: How much is this altogether?
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the question
exercises.explanation: 이거 (this) + 전부 (altogether) + 얼마예요 (how much is it) = How much is this altogether?

exercises.question: My phone number is 010-1234-5678.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 제 전화번호는 (my phone number is) + 공일공-일이삼사-오육칠팔입니다 (010-1234-5678)

lessons.title: Native Korean Numbers 1-10
lessons.description: Numbers used for counting objects and age
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Native Korean numbers are used for:
- Counting objects (with counters)
- Age (with 살)
- Hours (when telling time)

1=하나, 2=둘, 3=셋, 4=넷, 5=다섯
6=여섯, 7=일곱, 8=여덟, 9=아홉, 10=열

Note: When used with counters, 1-4 change form:
하나→한, 둘→두, 셋→세, 넷→네
lessons.grammar_tip: Native Korean numbers are used when counting things you can touch or see!

exercises.question: What is 'one' in Native Korean?
exercises.explanation: 하나 (hana) is 'one' in Native Korean

exercises.question: What number is 다섯?
exercises.explanation: 다섯 (daseot) means 5 in Native Korean

exercises.question: To say 'two apples', which number form do you use?
exercises.explanation: With counters, 둘 becomes 두, so it's 두 개 (two items)

exercises.question: What number is 열?
exercises.explanation: 열 (yeol) means 10 in Native Korean

exercises.question: Listen and select the counting phrase
exercises.instruction: Uses native Korean numbers with counters
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Please give me three apples.' (세 개 = 3 items)

exercises.question: Listen and identify the age statement
exercises.instruction: Korean uses native numbers for age
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'I am 25 years old.' (스물다섯 = 25)

exercises.question: How would you say you are 25 years old?
exercises.instruction: Korean uses native numbers for age with 살
exercises.explanation: Age uses Native Korean numbers + 살: 스물다섯 (25) + 살 (years old)

exercises.question: Actually, I need three more.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the statement
exercises.explanation: 사실 (actually) + 세 개 (three items) + 더 (more) + 필요해요 (I need) = Actually, I need three more.

exercises.question: I am 25 years old.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 스물다섯 (25) + 살 (years old) + 입니다 (am) - Uses native Korean numbers

lessons.title: Yes, No & Please
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Essential response words in Korean:

네 (ne) - Yes (polite)
아니요 (aniyo) - No (polite)
주세요 (juseyo) - Please give me...

네 can also mean 'I see' or 'I understand' in conversation.
lessons.grammar_tip: 네 sounds like 'neh' and is often repeated twice (네, 네) to show you're listening!

exercises.question: What does 네 mean?
exercises.explanation: 네 is the polite way to say 'yes'

exercises.question: What does 아니요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 아니요 is the polite way to say 'no'

exercises.question: How do you say 'Water, please'?
exercises.explanation: 물 (water) + 주세요 (please give me) = Water, please

exercises.question: What does 주세요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 주세요 means 'please give me' or just 'please' when requesting something

exercises.question: Listen and select the request phrase
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Please give me a glass of water.'

exercises.question: Listen and identify the response
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Yes, I understand. Please wait a moment.'

exercises.question: Of course! Would you like ice with that?
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the response
exercises.explanation: 물론이죠 (of course) + 얼음도 (ice too) + 드릴까요 (shall I give you) = Of course! Would you like ice with that?

exercises.question: Yes, I understand. I will do it now.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 네 알겠습니다 (yes, I understand) + 지금 바로 (right now) + 하겠습니다 (I will do it)

exercises.question: No thank you, I already ate.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 아니요 괜찮습니다 (no thank you) + 이미 먹었어요 (I already ate)

lessons.title: Excuse Me & Wait
lessons.description: Getting attention and asking to wait
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Useful phrases for getting attention:

저기요 (jeogiyo) - Excuse me (to get attention, like at a restaurant)
잠깐만요 (jamkkanmanyo) - Wait a moment / Just a second
실례합니다 (sillyehamnida) - Excuse me (more formal, when passing by)
lessons.grammar_tip: Use 저기요 when calling a waiter - it's like saying 'over there!'

exercises.question: How do you get a waiter's attention?
exercises.explanation: 저기요 is used to get someone's attention, like 'Excuse me!'

exercises.question: What does 잠깐만요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 잠깐만요 means 'wait a moment' or 'just a second'

exercises.question: Listen and select the question
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Where is the bathroom?'

exercises.question: Listen and identify the polite request
exercises.explanation: The sentence means 'Please wait a moment. I'll be right back.'

exercises.question: You need to pass by someone in a crowded place. What do you say?
exercises.explanation: 실례합니다 is used when excusing yourself to pass by someone

exercises.question: You're on the phone and someone is talking to you. What do you say to the caller?
exercises.explanation: 잠깐만요 asks the caller to wait a moment

exercises.question: Could you tell me where the exit is?
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the question
exercises.explanation: 출구가 (the exit) + 어디인지 (where it is) + 알려 주시겠어요 (could you tell me) = Could you tell me where the exit is?

exercises.question: Please wait here for a moment, I will be right back.
exercises.instruction: Arrange the Korean words to form the sentence
exercises.explanation: 여기서 (here) + 잠깐만 기다려 주세요 (please wait a moment) + 금방 올게요 (I'll be right back)

units.title: Daily Activities
units.description: Learn essential verbs for everyday actions

lessons.title: Basic Action Verbs
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Korean verbs end in -다 in dictionary form. When speaking politely, we change this to -아요/어요.

먹다 (meokda) → 먹어요 (meogeoyo) - to eat
마시다 (masida) → 마셔요 (masyeoyo) - to drink
가다 (gada) → 가요 (gayo) - to go
오다 (oda) → 와요 (wayo) - to come
lessons.grammar_tip: The -아요/어요 ending depends on the vowel in the verb stem. If it has ㅏ or ㅗ, use -아요. Otherwise, use -어요.

exercises.question: What does 먹다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 먹다 (meokda) means 'to eat' in Korean

exercises.question: What does 마시다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 마시다 (masida) means 'to drink' in Korean

exercises.question: What does 가다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 가다 (gada) means 'to go' in Korean

exercises.question: What does 오다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 오다 (oda) means 'to come' in Korean

exercises.question: How do you say 'I eat' politely?
exercises.explanation: 먹다 becomes 먹어요 in polite informal speech

exercises.question: Complete: 저는 물을 _____ (I drink water)
exercises.explanation: 마시다 becomes 마셔요 in polite speech

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: I study.

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: My friend works.

lessons.title: More Daily Verbs
lessons.description: Expand your vocabulary with more action verbs
lessons.grammar_explanation:
More essential daily verbs:

자다 (jada) → 자요 (jayo) - to sleep
일어나다 (ireonada) → 일어나요 (ireonayo) - to wake up
보다 (boda) → 봐요 (bwayo) - to see/watch
읽다 (ikda) → 읽어요 (ilgeoyo) - to read
lessons.grammar_tip: Practice conjugating verbs by removing -다 and adding -아요 or -어요!

exercises.question: What does 자다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 자다 (jada) means 'to sleep' in Korean

exercises.question: What does 보다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 보다 (boda) means 'to see' or 'to watch' in Korean

exercises.question: What does 읽다 mean?
exercises.explanation: 읽다 (ikda) means 'to read' in Korean

exercises.question: How do you say 'I watch TV' politely?
exercises.explanation: 보다 contracts to 봐요 in polite informal speech

exercises.question: Complete: 저는 책을 _____ (I read a book)
exercises.explanation: 읽다 becomes 읽어요 in polite speech

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: I exercise every day.

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: My older sister cooks.

units.title: Shopping & Money
units.description: Essential phrases for shopping in Korea

lessons.title: At the Store
lessons.description: Learn to ask prices and make purchases
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Essential shopping phrases:

이거 (igeo) - this (thing)
그거 (geugeo) - that (thing)
얼마예요? (eolmayeyo?) - How much is it?
주세요 (juseyo) - Please give me...
있어요? (isseoyo?) - Do you have...?
lessons.grammar_tip: Point at items and say '이거 얼마예요?' (How much is this?) - it works everywhere!

exercises.question: What does 이거 mean?
exercises.explanation: 이거 (igeo) means 'this (thing)' - used when pointing at something close to you

exercises.question: What does 얼마예요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 얼마예요? is used to ask the price of something

exercises.question: How do you ask 'How much is this?'
exercises.explanation: 이거 (this) + 얼마예요 (how much) = How much is this?

exercises.question: How do you say 'Please give me this'?
exercises.explanation: 이거 (this) + 주세요 (please give me) = Please give me this

exercises.question: What does 있어요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 있어요 means 'to have/exist'. As a question, it asks 'Do you have?' or 'Is there?'

exercises.question: A shopkeeper says '만 원이에요'. How much is it?
exercises.explanation: 만 (man) means 10,000, so 만 원 = 10,000 won

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: How much is this?

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: It's too expensive.

lessons.title: Shopping Conversations
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Useful shopping responses:

네, 있어요 (ne, isseoyo) - Yes, we have it
아니요, 없어요 (aniyo, eopseoyo) - No, we don't have it
너무 비싸요 (neomu bissayo) - It's too expensive
깎아 주세요 (kkakka juseyo) - Please give me a discount
lessons.grammar_tip: At traditional markets, you can often bargain! Try saying '깎아 주세요' politely.

exercises.question: What does 비싸요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 비싸요 means 'it's expensive'

exercises.question: What does 싸요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 싸요 means 'it's cheap' - the opposite of 비싸요

exercises.question: What does 없어요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 없어요 is the opposite of 있어요 - it means 'there isn't' or 'don't have'

exercises.question: How do you say 'It's too expensive'?
exercises.explanation: 너무 (too much) + 비싸요 (expensive) = It's too expensive

exercises.question: How do you ask for a discount?
exercises.explanation: 깎아 주세요 literally means 'please cut (the price)' - used to ask for a discount

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: Please give me a discount.

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: I'll pay by card.

units.title: Time & Weather
units.description: Talk about time, dates, and weather

lessons.title: Time Expressions
lessons.description: Learn to talk about when things happen
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Basic time words:

오늘 (oneul) - today
내일 (naeil) - tomorrow
어제 (eoje) - yesterday
지금 (jigeum) - now
나중에 (najunge) - later
lessons.grammar_tip: Time words usually come at the beginning of the sentence in Korean!

exercises.question: What does 오늘 mean?
exercises.explanation: 오늘 (oneul) means 'today'

exercises.question: What does 내일 mean?
exercises.explanation: 내일 (naeil) means 'tomorrow'

exercises.question: What does 어제 mean?
exercises.explanation: 어제 (eoje) means 'yesterday'

exercises.question: What does 지금 mean?
exercises.explanation: 지금 (jigeum) means 'now'

exercises.question: How do you say 'I'm going tomorrow'?
exercises.explanation: 내일 (tomorrow) + 가요 (go) = I'm going tomorrow

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: What time is it now?

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: It's 3:30.

lessons.title: Weather Talk
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Weather expressions:

날씨 (nalssi) - weather
덥다 (deopda) → 더워요 (deowoyo) - to be hot
춥다 (chupda) → 추워요 (chuwoyo) - to be cold
비가 와요 (biga wayo) - it's raining
눈이 와요 (nuni wayo) - it's snowing
lessons.grammar_tip: In Korean, rain and snow 'come' (와요) rather than 'fall'!

exercises.question: What does 날씨 mean?
exercises.explanation: 날씨 (nalssi) means 'weather'

exercises.question: What does 더워요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 더워요 means 'it's hot' (weather or feeling)

exercises.question: What does 추워요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 추워요 means 'it's cold' (weather or feeling)

exercises.question: How do you say 'It's raining'?
exercises.explanation: 비 (rain) + 가 (subject marker) + 와요 (comes) = It's raining

exercises.question: How do you say 'The weather is good today'?
exercises.explanation: 오늘 (today) + 날씨가 (weather) + 좋아요 (is good) = The weather is good today

exercises.question: What does 눈이 와요 mean?
exercises.explanation: 눈 (snow) + 이 (subject marker) + 와요 (comes) = It's snowing

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: How's the weather today?

exercises.question: Listen and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: Play the audio and choose the correct text
exercises.explanation: The sentence means: It's raining a lot.

units.title: Reading Practice
units.description: Practice reading and understanding Korean text passages

lessons.title: Simple Introductions
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Reading Korean text helps you recognize words and sentence patterns. Focus on:

1. **Subject markers**: 은/는, 이/가
2. **Object markers**: 을/를
3. **Common connectors**: 그리고 (and), 하지만 (but)
4. **Sentence endings**: -요 (polite), -습니다 (formal)
lessons.grammar_tip: When reading, look for familiar words first, then use context to understand new vocabulary.

exercises.question: What is the person's name?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 안녕하세요. 제 이름은 김민수예요. 저는 학생이에요. 서울에 살아요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '제 이름은 김민수예요' (My name is Kim Minsu)

exercises.question: Where does Kim Minsu live?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 안녕하세요. 제 이름은 김민수예요. 저는 학생이에요. 서울에 살아요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '서울에 살아요' (I live in Seoul)

exercises.question: What is Kim Minsu's occupation?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 안녕하세요. 제 이름은 김민수예요. 저는 학생이에요. 서울에 살아요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '저는 학생이에요' (I am a student)

exercises.question: What is the person's hobby?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 제 이름은 이영희예요. 저는 회사원이에요. 제 취미는 음악 듣기예요. 저는 K-pop을 좋아해요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '제 취미는 음악 듣기예요' (My hobby is listening to music)

lessons.title: Daily Routines
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Daily routine passages use time expressions and activity verbs:

**Time expressions**: 아침에 (in the morning), 저녁에 (in the evening)
**Activity verbs**: 일어나다 (to wake up), 먹다 (to eat), 가다 (to go)
**Frequency**: 매일 (every day), 보통 (usually)
lessons.grammar_tip: The particle -에 is used with time words to mean 'at' or 'in'.

exercises.question: What time does the person wake up?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 저는 매일 아침 7시에 일어나요. 아침을 먹고 학교에 가요. 학교는 9시에 시작해요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '매일 아침 7시에 일어나요' (I wake up at 7am every morning)

exercises.question: When does school start?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 저는 매일 아침 7시에 일어나요. 아침을 먹고 학교에 가요. 학교는 9시에 시작해요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '학교는 9시에 시작해요' (School starts at 9)

exercises.question: What does the person do on weekends?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 저는 주말에 친구들을 만나요. 우리는 카페에 가요. 커피를 마시고 이야기해요. 정말 재미있어요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '저는 주말에 친구들을 만나요' (I meet friends on weekends)

exercises.question: Where do they go together?
exercises.instruction: Read the passage and answer the question
exercises.content_text: 저는 주말에 친구들을 만나요. 우리는 카페에 가요. 커피를 마시고 이야기해요. 정말 재미있어요.
exercises.explanation: The passage says '우리는 카페에 가요' (We go to a cafe)

lessons.title: Signs and Notices
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Korean signs use simple, direct language:

**Common signs**:
- 출구 (exit)
- 입구 (entrance)
- 화장실 (restroom)
- 금지 (prohibited)
- 주의 (caution)

**Command forms**: -세요 (please do), 지 마세요 (please don't)
lessons.grammar_tip: Signs often omit particles for brevity.

exercises.question: What does this sign mean?
exercises.instruction: Read and select the correct meaning
exercises.content_text: 출구 →
exercises.explanation: 출구 (chulgu) means 'exit'

exercises.question: What does this sign tell you to do?
exercises.instruction: Read and select the correct meaning
exercises.content_text: 조용히 하세요
exercises.explanation: 조용히 하세요 means 'please be quiet'

exercises.question: What is prohibited here?
exercises.instruction: Read and select the correct meaning
exercises.content_text: 흡연 금지
exercises.explanation: 흡연 (smoking) + 금지 (prohibited) = No smoking

exercises.question: Where is this sign pointing to?
exercises.content_text: 화장실 ← 왼쪽
exercises.explanation: 화장실 (restroom) + 왼쪽 (left) with arrow pointing left

lessons.title: Simple Messages
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Korean text messages use both formal and casual language:

**Casual endings**: -어/아 (basic form), -ㄹ게 (I will)
**Formal endings**: -어요/아요, -습니다

**Common abbreviations**:
- ㅋㅋ (haha)
- ㅇㅋ (OK)
- ㄱㅅ (thanks)
lessons.grammar_tip: Casual Korean often drops particles and uses shortened forms.

exercises.question: What is the person asking?
exercises.content_text: 지금 어디야? 같이 점심 먹을래?
options: Where are you? Want to eat lunch together?
What time is it? Let's have dinner.
Where are you going? See you later.
What are you doing? Let's study.
exercises.correct_answer: Where are you? Want to eat lunch together?
exercises.explanation: 지금 어디야 (where are you now) + 같이 점심 먹을래 (want to eat lunch together)

exercises.question: What time does the movie start?
exercises.content_text: 영화는 7시에 시작해. 6시 30분에 만나자!
exercises.explanation: 영화는 7시에 시작해 (the movie starts at 7)

exercises.question: Why can't the person come?
exercises.content_text: 미안해. 오늘 못 가. 감기 걸렸어. 다음에 보자.
exercises.explanation: 감기 걸렸어 means 'caught a cold'

exercises.question: What is the person's response?
exercises.content_text: A: 내일 시간 있어? B: 응, 있어. 왜? A: 같이 쇼핑 갈래?
exercises.explanation: 응, 있어 means 'yes, I have time' (informal)

lessons.title: Schedules and Plans
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Schedules use specific time and date expressions:

**Days**: 월요일 (Monday), 화요일 (Tuesday), etc.
**Dates**: 1월 1일 (January 1st)
**Duration**: ~부터 ~까지 (from ~ to ~)

**Future tense**: -(으)ㄹ 거예요 (will/going to)
lessons.grammar_tip: Korean dates follow the order: year > month > day.

exercises.question: When is the Korean test?
exercises.content_text:
이번 주 일정:
월요일 - 수학 시험
수요일 - 영어 수업
금요일 - 한국어 시험
exercises.explanation: 금요일 - 한국어 시험 (Friday - Korean test)

exercises.question: What time is the meeting?
exercises.content_text:
5월 15일 일정:
오전 9시 - 팀 회의
오후 2시 - 점심 약속
오후 5시 - 퇴근
exercises.explanation: 오전 9시 - 팀 회의 (9am - team meeting)

lessons.title: Short Stories
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Stories use past, present, and future tenses:

**Past**: -았/었어요 (did)
**Present**: -어요/아요 (do/does)
**Future**: -(으)ㄹ 거예요 (will do)

**Conjunctions**: 그래서 (so/therefore), 그런데 (but/however), 그리고 (and)
lessons.grammar_tip: Pay attention to time markers to understand when events happen.

exercises.question: What did Jisu do yesterday?
exercises.content_text: 어제 지수는 도서관에 갔어요. 2시간 동안 공부했어요. 그리고 친구를 만났어요. 같이 커피를 마셨어요. 정말 좋은 하루였어요.
exercises.explanation: 지수는 도서관에 갔어요 (Jisu went to the library)

exercises.question: How long did Jisu study?
exercises.content_text: 어제 지수는 도서관에 갔어요. 2시간 동안 공부했어요. 그리고 친구를 만났어요. 같이 커피를 마셨어요. 정말 좋은 하루였어요.
exercises.explanation: 2시간 동안 공부했어요 (studied for 2 hours)

exercises.question: What is Minho's problem?
exercises.content_text: 민호는 요즘 바빠요. 회사 일이 많아요. 그래서 친구들을 못 만나요. 주말에도 일해요. 민호는 휴가가 필요해요.
exercises.explanation: 민호는 요즘 바빠요 (Minho is busy these days) and 회사 일이 많아요 (has a lot of work)

exercises.question: What does Minho need?
exercises.content_text: 민호는 요즘 바빠요. 회사 일이 많아요. 그래서 친구들을 못 만나요. 주말에도 일해요. 민호는 휴가가 필요해요.
exercises.explanation: 민호는 휴가가 필요해요 (Minho needs a vacation)

lessons.title: Sentence Completion
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Writing helps you internalize grammar patterns. Focus on:

1. **Proper particles**: 은/는, 이/가, 을/를
2. **Verb conjugations**: -어요/아요 endings
3. **Spacing**: Korean uses spaces between words
lessons.grammar_tip: When writing, think about particle usage - it's crucial for correct Korean!

exercises.question: Complete: 저는 ___ 학생이에요. (I am a student)
exercises.instruction: Fill in the blank with the correct word/phrase
exercises.explanation: 학생이에요 means 'am a student'

exercises.question: Complete: 안녕하세요. 제 이름은 ___. (Hello. My name is Kim Minsu)
exercises.explanation: 김민수예요 is the polite form for 'is Kim Minsu'

exercises.question: Complete: 저는 서울에 ___. (I live in Seoul)
exercises.instruction: Fill in the blank with the correct verb
exercises.explanation: 살아요 means 'live' (present tense, polite)

exercises.question: Complete: 오늘 날씨가 ___. (Today's weather is good)
exercises.explanation: 좋아요 means 'is good' (polite form)

exercises.question: Complete: 저는 한국어를 ___. (I study Korean)
exercises.instruction: Fill in the blank with the correct verb
exercises.explanation: 공부해요 means 'study' (present tense, polite)

exercises.question: Complete: 매일 아침 7시에 ___. (I wake up at 7am every morning)
exercises.explanation: 일어나요 means 'wake up' (polite form)

exercises.question: Complete: 저는 커피를 ___. (I drink coffee)
exercises.instruction: Fill in the blank with the correct verb
exercises.explanation: 마셔요 means 'drink' (polite form)

exercises.question: Complete: 친구를 ___. (I meet friends)
exercises.explanation: 만나요 means 'meet' (polite form)

lessons.title: Basic Translation
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Translation requires understanding:

**Word order**: Korean is SOV (Subject-Object-Verb)
**Particles**: Mark grammatical roles
**Politeness**: Choose appropriate ending (-요, -습니다)

Example: 'I like apples'
- 저는 (I) + 사과를 (apples) + 좋아해요 (like)
lessons.grammar_tip: Remember: Korean verbs come at the end of the sentence!

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: Hello
exercises.explanation: 안녕하세요 is the standard polite greeting

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: Thank you
exercises.explanation: 감사합니다 is the polite way to say 'thank you'

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: I am a student
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 학생 (student) + 이에요 (am)

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: I like coffee
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 커피를 (coffee) + 좋아해요 (like)

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: The weather is good
exercises.explanation: 날씨가 (weather) + 좋아요 (is good)

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: It's delicious
exercises.explanation: 맛있어요 means 'it's delicious' (polite form)

exercises.question: Translate to Korean: See you tomorrow
exercises.explanation: 내일 (tomorrow) + 봐요 (see you)

lessons.title: Form Filling
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Forms require specific information formats:

**Name**: 이름 (ireum)
**Age**: 나이 (nai) or 살 (sal)
**Phone**: 전화번호 (jeonhwa beonho)
**Address**: 주소 (juso)

Numbers can be Sino-Korean or Native Korean depending on context.
lessons.grammar_tip: Age uses native Korean numbers + 살 (years old).

exercises.question: Write 'student' in Korean
exercises.explanation: 학생 (haksaeng) means student

exercises.question: Write 'Seoul' in Korean
exercises.explanation: 서울 is Seoul in Korean

exercises.question: Write '25 years old' in Korean
exercises.explanation: 스물다섯 (25) + 살 (years old)

exercises.question: Write 'South Korea' in Korean
exercises.explanation: 한국 (hanguk) means South Korea

exercises.question: Write 'male' in Korean
exercises.explanation: 남자 (namja) means male

lessons.title: Short Responses
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Short answers require appropriate formality:

**Informal**: -어/아 (to friends)
**Polite**: -어요/아요 (general)
**Formal**: -습니다/ㅂ니다 (very polite)

Match your formality level to the question!
lessons.grammar_tip: If the question uses -요, respond with -요 too!

exercises.question: Q: 이름이 뭐예요? (What's your name?) A: ___
exercises.instruction: Write your response (use: 제 이름은 김민수예요)
exercises.explanation: 제 이름은 (my name is) + 김민수예요

exercises.question: Q: 어디에 살아요? (Where do you live?) A: ___
exercises.explanation: 서울에 (in Seoul) + 살아요 (live)

exercises.question: Q: 뭐 해요? (What are you doing?) A: ___
exercises.explanation: 공부해요 means 'I'm studying'

exercises.question: Q: 커피 좋아해요? (Do you like coffee?) A: 네, ___
exercises.instruction: Write your response (yes, I like it)
exercises.explanation: 네 (yes) + 좋아해요 (I like it)

exercises.question: Q: 오늘 날씨가 어때요? (How's the weather today?) A: ___
exercises.explanation: 좋아요 means 'it's good'

exercises.question: Q: 몇 시에 일어나요? (What time do you wake up?) A: ___
exercises.explanation: 7시에 (at 7 o'clock) + 일어나요 (wake up)

exercises.question: Q: 취미가 뭐예요? (What's your hobby?) A: ___
exercises.instruction: Write your response (listening to music: 음악 듣기)
exercises.explanation: 제 취미는 (my hobby is) + 음악 듣기예요 (listening to music)

exercises.question: Q: 한국어 공부해요? (Do you study Korean?) A: 네, ___
exercises.explanation: 네 (yes) + 공부해요 (I study)

exercises.question: Q: 점심 먹었어요? (Did you eat lunch?) A: 네, ___
exercises.explanation: 네 (yes) + 먹었어요 (I ate) - past tense

exercises.question: Q: 주말에 뭐 할 거예요? (What will you do on the weekend?) A: ___
exercises.instruction: Write your response (I'll meet friends: 친구들을 만나다)
exercises.explanation: 친구들을 (friends) + 만날 거예요 (will meet) - future tense

lessons.title: Sentence Construction
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Sentence construction follows patterns:

**Basic**: Subject + Verb
- 저는 가요 (I go)

**With object**: Subject + Object + Verb
- 저는 밥을 먹어요 (I eat rice)

**With time/place**: Time/Place + Subject + Verb
- 오늘 저는 학교에 가요 (Today I go to school)
lessons.grammar_tip: Build sentences step by step: add subject, then object, then verb!

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I eat rice (저/밥/먹다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 밥을 (rice) + 먹어요 (eat)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I go to school (저/학교/가다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 학교에 (to school) + 가요 (go)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I meet friends (저/친구들/만나다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 친구들을 (friends) + 만나요 (meet)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I study Korean (저/한국어/공부하다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 한국어를 (Korean) + 공부해요 (study)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I drink coffee (저/커피/마시다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 커피를 (coffee) + 마셔요 (drink)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I read a book (저/책/읽다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 책을 (book) + 읽어요 (read)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: Today I go to a cafe (오늘/저/카페/가다)
exercises.explanation: 오늘 (today) + 저는 (I) + 카페에 (to cafe) + 가요 (go)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: Tomorrow I will meet a teacher (내일/저/선생님/만나다)
exercises.instruction: Use: 내일, 저는, 선생님을, 만날 거예요
exercises.explanation: 내일 (tomorrow) + 저는 (I) + 선생님을 (teacher) + 만날 거예요 (will meet)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I like music (저/음악/좋아하다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 음악을 (music) + 좋아해요 (like)

exercises.question: Write a sentence: I watch a movie (저/영화/보다)
exercises.explanation: 저는 (I) + 영화를 (movie) + 봐요 (watch)

lessons.title: Listening Comprehension Practice
lessons.description: Practice understanding Korean through dialogues, announcements, and phone conversations
lessons.grammar_explanation:
Listening comprehension is crucial for real-world Korean communication. This lesson includes:

1. **Dialogues**: Natural conversations between two or more people
2. **Announcements**: Public notices you might hear in stations, stores, or airports
3. **Phone Conversations**: Common phone etiquette and expressions

Tips for listening:
- Listen for keywords first
- Pay attention to tone and context
- Don't worry if you don't catch every word
- Listen multiple times if needed
lessons.grammar_tip: In spoken Korean, particles are often dropped in casual conversation. For example, '나 학교 가' instead of '나는 학교에 가'.

exercises.question: Listen to this dialogue and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a natural conversation between two people
exercises.korean_text: A: 어디 가세요? B: 도서관에 가요. 공부하러 가요.
options: A: 어디 가세요? B: 도서관에 가요. 공부하러 가요.
exercises.correct_answer: A: 어디 가세요? B: 도서관에 가요. 공부하러 가요.
exercises.explanation:
A: Where are you going? B: I'm going to the library. I'm going to study.

Context: Casual conversation about destination

exercises.question: Listen to this dialogue and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a natural conversation between two people
exercises.korean_text: A: 점심 먹었어요? B: 아니요, 아직 안 먹었어요.
options: A: 점심 먹었어요? B: 아니요, 아직 안 먹었어요.
exercises.correct_answer: A: 점심 먹었어요? B: 아니요, 아직 안 먹었어요.
exercises.explanation:
A: Did you eat lunch? B: No, I haven't eaten yet.

Context: Asking about meals

exercises.question: Listen to this dialogue and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a natural conversation between two people
exercises.korean_text: A: 주말에 뭐 할 거예요? B: 친구들하고 영화 볼 거예요.
options: A: 주말에 뭐 할 거예요? B: 친구들하고 영화 볼 거예요.
exercises.correct_answer: A: 주말에 뭐 할 거예요? B: 친구들하고 영화 볼 거예요.
exercises.explanation:
A: What will you do on the weekend? B: I'm going to watch a movie with friends.

Context: Making weekend plans

exercises.question: Listen to this dialogue and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a natural conversation between two people
exercises.korean_text: A: 이 옷 어때요? B: 정말 예쁘네요! 잘 어울려요.
options: A: 이 옷 어때요? B: 정말 예쁘네요! 잘 어울려요.
exercises.correct_answer: A: 이 옷 어때요? B: 정말 예쁘네요! 잘 어울려요.
exercises.explanation:
A: How's this outfit? B: It's really pretty! It suits you well.

Context: Shopping for clothes

exercises.question: Listen to this dialogue and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a natural conversation between two people
exercises.korean_text: A: 커피 마실래요? B: 좋아요! 카페에 가요.
options: A: 커피 마실래요? B: 좋아요! 카페에 가요.
exercises.correct_answer: A: 커피 마실래요? B: 좋아요! 카페에 가요.
exercises.explanation:
A: Want to drink coffee? B: Sounds good! Let's go to a cafe.

Context: Inviting someone for coffee

exercises.question: Listen to this dialogue and select what you hear
exercises.instruction: This is a natural conversation between two people
